content.description: An atypical boulder for the Foothills: steep with actual solid holds making it perhaps the best boulder problem in the Foothills. Fairfield got the FA and Jon Cardwell later flashed it for the SA.
content.location:
Starting on right facing pinches low and right, make the very technical and demanding moves to gain access to the good crimps at about head level. Continue left across the mid-section to the committing throw to the lip and mantle. Falling from the lip would be bad as the landing is very uneven over large boulders. 

  The stand start is most likely V8 and a direct low start that has yet to be done could check in at the V13/14 range

content.description: Starting on Screaming Jihad and head straight up through decent crimps to mantle.

Some call this v13, some call it v12, either way this is the less committing brother of Screaming Jihad. Start as for Screaming Jihad until you get to the crimps at head height and then go straight up via powerful moves to finish on Blue Valentine.
content.location: Down and right on right facing pinches

content.description:
This problem starts on the cool undercling feature about head height on the arete and continues up though interesting holds. The challenge is trying to establish yourself on the upper section via intermediate moves on bad slopers in order to grab the good right-handed ledge and top out.  

  Very good rock and unique holds/movement.
content.location: Around the corner from Screaming Jihad

content.description: A direct(ish) variation to Screaming Jihad that revolves around a terrible right hand pinch and a difficult lock-off/high-step.
content.location: Starting almost head height on Screaming Jihad with the good left hand rail and right hand on the good right hand crimp, make the long reach up and right to a terrible pinch; lock it off, get your foot up and grab the top. It's only about two moves (based on the original sequence) but it's hard the whole way.

content.description: Perhaps the single most mythical boulder in the Sandias? The full package: technical, long, hard and intimidating with amazing rock.
